name: Alberta Benchmark Survey 2008: What Adults Know About Child Development
description: The Alberta Benchmark Survey (2008) is a computer-assisted telephone survey that aimed to learn what adults and parents in Alberta knew about children's developmental milestones and strategies to support optimal child development. As well, the survey aimed to obtain information about Albertans' beliefs about child care and children's issues, where parents obtained information about child development, and what parenting strategies they used. Individuals living in Alberta and over the age of 18 were eligible if they had contact with a child under the age of 14 within 6 months and had a phone that could be accessed by random direct dialing. These metadata are also available through SAGE's searchable metadata website: http://sagemetadata.policywise.com/nada/index.php/catalog/5
spatialCoverage: Calgary Health Region, Alberta; Capital Health Region, Alberta; Rural Health Regions, Alberta

distribution.name: Benchmark2008_FinalReport
distribution.description: Contains the final report about the results of the 2008 Benchmark Survey: What Adults Know About Child Development. Outlines major findings from the survey

distribution.name: Benchmark2008_metadata.pdf
distribution.description: This file contains the full metadata entry for the 2008 Alberta Benchmark Survey: What Adults Know About Child Development. Includes element-level metadata
